comments.commentBody: Slink home to her family?  That is not what I have read.  Her husband works for the governor and is paid $91,400 a year.  I imagine she is filled with fear that he will lose his job too.  They also said her "job" was a sham!
@Tom. So the point is that concern about access to nuclear materials is paranoia and the real threat is the U.S.? Remarkable.

How can anyone who calls themselves a 'conservative' support the burning of fossil fuels.  With large doubts about the predictions of climate scientists wouldn't a conservative person be more risk averse and want to dramatically reduce the fossil fuel usage 'just in case.'  I think we should all be very conservative and conserve our fossil fuels to be burned in thrifty amounts over many centuries ahead.
The election is already grossly manipulated by the media. The NYT currently has 6 articles on Trump front and centre and Bernie really gets precious little coverage.

A problem with so-called "strategic voting" is that an election is then subject to manipulation by the media, or an organization with a lot of influence on the media.  Moneyed interests can create a myth that, based on polls or other non-verifiable information, Candidate X is bound to win unless people vote for Candidate Z, who has no chance of winning but can deny the race for X.  The media amplify the myth.  Now we have voters who are voting under this influence and denying Candidate Y from winning.  In other words, strategic voting is based on some pre-determined view of the outcome, which is subject to manipulation.  A dangerous idea in a real democracy.
Both youse guys, M and M, seem to be overlooking the center of the grid. AND is a plus (Oh, a pun, Howie God Bless ye).

Obviously, I do not know who will win the fall general election, but this analysis appears incorrect to me.  Both Trump and Cruz have very high negatives.  Trump's are extraordinary and unprecedented.  If he is the nominee, it seems very unlikely he could defeat Clinton (despite her own unfortunate negatives), and he might even be unable to beat Sanders.  Although one frequently sees the claim that Clinton supporters are unenthusiastic, polls, particularly of African-American voters, show high levels of enthusiasm.   And Trump has alienated women to a spectacular degree.  Krugman may well be within his rights to presume a Clinton victory.

The medical insurance companies will only cover birth control if it is for the purpose of preventing pregnancy. If you need it to control dysmennorhea or PMDD, but you don't have sex, you have to lie and say you are sexually active in order to get the medical insurance company to cover this expensive medicine that costs about $50/month at least.

It's really hard for me to believe that in modern day America this case has even come up. It's clear the organizations in question, which are not actual churches, want more then the ability not to have to pay for birth control pills. No, what they want instead is the ability to impose their religious beliefs and rules on their employees of whatever age or religious bent. And that violates the First Amendment.

I thought it interesting we're talking about anti-contraceptives, when these pills do more then prevent pregnancy. They are used also for regulating the hormonal cycle to control the growth of uterine fibroids, a condition from which I was suffered. Would the little sisters of the poor require employees to specifically state the nature of the reason for needing these products? I wonder why that argument didn't come before the court!

The other thing that bugged me here was the admittance by the religious organizations that they are "equal opportunity employers. " That belies the nature of this case, since if religion is not a litmus test for hiring as they state, then why is it their business to impose on employees their Catholic beliefs?

Their employees are not nuns themselves, even if the sisters are acting as if they were.

.
I left out one of the thoughts I had while doing the puzzle.
-- Considering some recent Comments, my first thought at 28 Down was "gun licenses"; fortunately the entry-length was wrong.

The Golden State Warriors have 3 straight home-games coming up, against teams that lack excellence on the road. That scheduling makes it more likely than not that they will come very close to an NBA season record for wins. But their final 4 games of the regular season are more interesting to me. They play 2 teams twice each [although neither pair of games is a Home-AND-Home set].
That's why I chose cremation. Don't want to be floating around Manhattan.

While climate is indeed a complex adaptive system it is one based on a foundation of well established physical processes for which we have extremely well developed mathematical relationships. This level of quantitative foundation does not exist for economic systems since in economics you are attempting to capture human behavior with equations.

Complex physical models have much greater predictive skill and stable performance than social science models (I have considerable experience in developing and using both). Yes there is uncertainty and addressing that is a large part of studies like this but the uncertainty is not at all as great as your are suggesting.

Climate change is a long process. However, when it reaches a threshold, it can happen much faster and more drastically. I will most likely be dead by then, but most of us have kids. Is it human nature to procrastinate and hope it's never too late?

What if?????

What if the story of Noahs' Ark was really a prophecy of the coming future as many Biblical prophecies are believed to be...................

What if?????

Hi,
Not sure why you think there is nothing to be done. The article noted that a far more stringent effort to limit emissions of greenhouse gases would stand a fairly good chance of saving West Antarctica from collapse.
Warm regards,
Don

It needs to be realized: There is no prospect of preventing the ice sheets from melting, independent of man's activities. None whatsoever. The issue is: When?

What would happen if, say, all carbon dioxide and, more critically, methane emissions were suddenly reduced to zero? The warming would continue, albeit at a slower pace, and New York would be flooded in 200 years instead of 80.

That only gives us more time to abandon the doomed coastal cities -- not to hold back the inevitable.

Yes, this is a wake up call -- not to wring our hands and buy more electric vehicles (which need energy to be charged -- but that's another discussion) -- but rather to plan our response to this inevitability. Start with a new mantra: "Move out of Manhattan, let the sea take it." There really is no alternative, whatever amelioration is adopted.

Accept the reality, and make plans for coping with it. The sky really is falling.

Excellent question. What about the influence of banks as well?  On a recent visit to Miami, I was amazed at the funding of enormous development project as water levels continue to rise.  I suppose they don't think past the timeline of a mortgage repayment schedule, but even that is under threat now.

You may be interested in this bay in Nova Scotia, Canada.
http://bayoffundytourism.com
Meaning what?  Just give up?

It's foolish to mention local US politics as a fix. I spend time traveling through Southeast Asia where the mega cities spew so much pollution and carbon in the air that on most days you can not see the sky.  The third world developing countries and China appear to care less about carbon emissions. You can learn a lot by traveling and seeing with your one eyes.

A major shift in government policy thinking must occur from that of replacing fossil fuel use with renewable energy to energy conservation.

Conservation efforts can have profound impacts NOW. Weatherizing all forms of structures should reduce energy use by thirty percent as I have done at low cost in this home. I already drive less and walk more knowing the importance of energy conservation and the health benefits of walking.

Just remember this wherever you are; Is It ON?......Turn It OFF!

Nonetheless, there is STILL NO SUCH THING AS GLOBAL WARMING!
Amirite, Repubs?
Biggest hoax in the history of mankind!

Until Trump came along, that is.

Preaching to the choir here at the New York Times. Text Donald Trump and let him know that his mansion in Florida will be underwater soon. In Fact all his properties will be underwater. Tell Ted Cruz, this is what God wants and will mess up his presidency in 2100. Maybe these titans can stop the rising oceans. There is no other way.

I was surprised, looking at the map, how Antarctica is not so much a continent as a multiple series of large islands.

At what point will the shelf ice melt, to the extent its weight simply become buoyant, and the entire mass displaces the ocean? Once it's afloat its ocean displacement will be the same whether its as ice or liquid.

And how will this affect Ocean salinity, as well as warm and cold currents? And the plants, fish and mammals that would be affected?

Would NY's or Ireland's Gulf Current's warming affect disappear? or California's chilling Arctic Current?

Wouldn't all of that compound into an environmental, geographic, sociological disaster far beyond, and making far worse the rising sea level and disappearing coasts.
Amen!

Cue Dick Cheney of Halliburton -- remember how he schooled us that ecologically sound actions are merely an optional "private virtue" and not the proper subject of public policy?

It is depressingly obvious that individual actions will never, ever make the difference here.

Read "The Tragedy of the Commons" if you don't understand why.

Glancing over the comments here I can see a lot of the usual ventilation about "greedy capitalists" and so forth, but the truth is that people acting individually can affect climate by making choices to not eat meat, not drive a car when they could ride a bike, and so forth. The most significant difference people can make is electing to not have children.

That said, increasing air and water temperatures will lead to more precipitation over Antarctica, which will continue to be a sub-freezing place (for the most part), and so glaciers will continue tp accrue there even if there is some instability on the margins. If anyone claims definite predictions about sea level 100 years from now based on computer models I wouldn't get all that excited about it quite yet. But for those who are concerned, as pointed out above, your life style choices do make a difference.

James Powell and Gordon Danby are great scientists. I was fortunate to hear them when they testified before the US Senate Environment & Public Works Committee, Chaired by Senator Moynihan of NY who rediscovered them & Maglev in 1987 and he requested that they appear and testify. They did & were asked to lead a study committee of Maglev & transportation experts, The report made a convincing case that a Maglev transport network capable of carrying both trucks & passengers at an average speed of 300 mph and also capable of electronic switching and operating on conventional railroads on Maglev adapted railroad tracks should be our next surface transport system to add capacity to our aging, costly and congested Interstate Highway System. This became a bi-partisan RDTE proposal to the Senate and it passed but it failed to get out of Committee in the House because of strong opposition of existing transport interests. Clearly, a huge mistake because this all-electric, all-weather, low-maintenance, no-emissions, lower cost system is perfect for the challenge that we now face. In 2000, Powell & Danby were awarded the Franklin Medal for Engineering.

BNL's 50th anniversary celebration of the 1966 SC Maglev invention. https://youtu.be/_pikyp8Y-vQ?t=6m49s

They have written about this remarkable technology in "The Fight for Maglev ", "Maglev America", "Startram: The Next Race to Space", & soon will publish "Silent Earth", bringing a technology solution to Global Warming challenge.
And Governor Scott of Florida (a/k/a Governor Toilet Paper--Scott Tissue) continues to forbid the state to use the term "global warming." He deserves to go down the toilet of history in infamy.
